name: Anonymous
com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9478360

SNES port had better colors and a better spu.

The colors on the genesis port LOOKED brighter because the colors were mostly primaries, rather than the shades in the SNES's wider palette. E.g. the pink flamingos in the Hong Kong bg.

And also, no fart sounds in the SNES.

However, genesis had a better cpu and a bit more memory. Which meant the bgm could keep going between rounds, livelier backgrounds/npc's and decals (as in the arcade), and more sprites.

So, there was no moonwalking as in the snes port. The retreat/backward animation sprites are still there in the genesis port.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Basically just start turning about 2 seconds before it looks like you would need to turn. Its a bit like a really fast version of sega rally so you want to be drifting around most corners and just tapping the d pad. Also don't over correct the car too much, just let go on the d pad after a fast corner and use tiny taps to straighten up. Its my favorite saturn racing game. You can play in manual mode as once you are in top gear you never really need to change gears except a couple of hairpins. I would only play this if you can get past the last level of sega rally every time.

The "programmable" logic is chicken bits which is basically the same as giving you options for configuring the hardware to do one of N programmed presets, but that's not true reprogrammability. I'm also not arguing the viability of the masses wanting FPGAs directly but it's the fact that at some point, it will be needed due to the end of Moore's law on the performance front.
FPGAs aren't just programmable ASICs, the name tells you as much. But the applications where FPGAs can't apply like analog where you can't just get it to emulate a photonic processor or temperature sensor are only relevant issues in industrial fields which we aren't talking about and which emulation doesn't actually need. The I/O options given are to alleviate that shortcoming. I don't disagree that it will take a while to get them put into general purpose CPUs but that they will happen at some point and that is when they actually get cheap. Until then, you are right that it's the MISTer or nothing until Terasic decides to move away from the Cyclone V and subsidize something else.

I don't have a complete list, but I know these six are ones I wouldn't do without:
Time Crisis
Area 51
Tekken Tag Tournament
Ultimate Mortal Kombat 3
Chronicles of Mysteria
Gauntlet: Dark Legacy

I think the key to success for arcades is to provide things that you can't easily replicate on a home console: Unique controls like light guns, steering wheels/racing pedals, joysticks, etc that the average person wouldn't have, games that thrive on having your opponent in person and a crowd watching you, and games that are best played co-op with friends. The only other problem is that you need to keep getting fresh entertainment with new games or content, but I think that could be solved pretty easily in the modern era of internet connectivity and devs providing updates.

name: Anonymous
com:
Someone posted this image on /ck/ and it reminded me how much I hated pre-rendered backgrounds in 3d games as a kid. Growing up with the SNES and Genesis, I remember the first game we got in 3D was Mario 64, which gives you a very physical, tactile environment where your character interacts with every surface and edge. Then you play something like Zelda or Final Fantasy of the same generation and you get these weird environments where you never feel like your character collides with anything, like your character is running around in a clear box with invisible walls and there is a background superimposed via green screen. As I got older and understood why it was made that way I appreciated the effort and extra detail allowed by it, but as a kid it always bugged me and still does to a degree.

Did this bother anyone else as a kid or just me?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: It looked great on my TV. Obviously on most emulator settings it looks bizarre. But I do remember these prerendered OOT backgrounds looking very realistic and detailed as opposed to most low poly interiors in the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9479341
yeah, N64 emulators in particular make them look awful.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: My first experience with OoT was at the store, with Link running around Hyrule town. I thought it was an awful way to play the game and wondered why they didn't just put the camera behind Link. Obviously a minute later I ran into an actual 3D area and it was better, but then I hated the disconnect of the graphical quality. The game should have be actual 3D with consistent graphics the whole way through, even if the camera is locked somewhere, which it should generally avoid.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9478982
at risk of outing myself as a zoomer, I'll share my lil anecdote
For context, my first time really playing OOT was with the collectors disc bundled with the gamecube around 2003. So by then I was aware that the game was older but I still enjoyed it as if it was new, I was playing my n64 up until that point anyways.
First time I walked into hyrule castle town, even on a CRT I recognized that it looked "bad" as in the image was clearly not the highest quality, but it wasnt jarring at all.
As an adult having went back and played FF7, I love the pre rendered backgrounds but that shit is jarring and actually gets in the way of gameplay sometimes. OOT is a lot more subtle and doesnt try to do too much, which I think helps

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9471906
According to Kim Newman in the book Nightmare Movies (2011), the "zombie revival began in the Far East" during the late 1990s, largely inspired by the Japanese zombie games Resident Evil and The House of the Dead. The success of these two 1996 zombie games inspired a wave of Asian zombie films, such as Bio Zombie (1998) and Versus (2000), for example.[18] The zombie revival which began in the Far East eventually went global following the worldwide success of Japanese zombie games such as Resident Evil and The House of the Dead. Their success led to a wave of Western zombie films during the 2000s, such as 28 Days Later (2002) and Shaun of the Dead (2004), for example.[18] In 2013, George Romero said it was the video games Resident Evil and House of the Dead "more than anything else" that popularised his zombie concept in mainstream popular culture.[19][20]

The House of the Dead has also been credited with introducing a new type of zombie distinct from Romero's classic slow zombie: the fast running zombie. After first appearing in The House of the Dead, they became popular in zombie films and video games during the 2000s, including the Resident Evil games and films, The House of the Dead film adaptation, and the films 28 Days Later (2002) and Dawn of the Dead (2004).[21]

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464058
I'll be honest, when I was in my 20s, Raiden was a big turn-off for me compared to MGS1 as Snake. I don't think he was a good fit for a series at the time was taken as a spy/james bond type game primarily played by guys who liked that sort of thing. It was especially a bait to play as Snake for an hour before being thrown into Raiden's shoes without warning for the rest of the game.

I also didn't like the characters as much as MGS1 except for Solidus, the Liquid living on through an arm transplant to Ocelot was beyond stupid and just got even worse through MGS4, your support staff was overall more bland and less interesting than MGS1 (I get that Colonel was to be an AI recreation and thus his advice and personality are supposed to be flat, but still), Fortune and Vamp were completely over the top, and Fatman was good but silly didn't fit the theme. MGS3 had its fair share of camp, but still felt more grounded overall than MGS2.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9464109
I think it also has to do with just age. There's a lot of games that wouldn't get the time of day on release because there were better ones that you'd spend your limited time on. Fast forward fifteen years and now when games release at a glacial pace and are unappealing to older audiences who grew up with video games, now suddenly games that weren't regarded well on release get more attention because the landscape is starved for fresh entertainment.

I recently started playing through the PSX library and started quite a few games that I saw but passed on during its lifetime because I couldn't play everything at once and found myself enjoying them. There's nothing modern I'd rather play, so I'm perfectly content playing something that decent but not great because it's still a type of game I'd want to play over the latest PS5 releases.
